questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of several painless, pruritic lesions on his left forearm that he first noticed 4 days ago. They were initially pink marks that progressed into blisters before ulcerating. He has also had a headache for 1 week. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). A photograph of one of the lesions is shown. There is pronounced edema of the surrounding skin and painless swelling of the left axillary lymph nodes. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Swimming in pools is a risk factor for Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis (hot tub folliculitis). It typically develops within 48 hours after exposure to the pathogen in pools or tubs and presents with tender and pruritic papules, pustules, or nodules. Most patients can have associated malaise and low-grade fever. However, an isolated necrotic eschar would not be seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug reactions can manifest with several different cutaneous findings (e.g., drug rash, fixed drug reaction). However, there is no known drug that would cause an isolated eschar with surrounding edema, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, his systemic symptoms (fever, headache, lymphadenopathy) are more suggestive of an infection than of an adverse drug reaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Cat scratch disease, caused by Bartonella henselae transmitted from cat scratches or bites, causes lesions that begin as a single papule or pustule. However, the hallmark sign of the disease is the development of tender regional lymphadenopathy. A necrotic eschar would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is associated with several cutaneous infections, including necrobiosis lipoidica and acanthosis nigricans. In uncontrolled diabetics, necrotic eschars may form in conjunction with mucormycosis, usually seen in the facial region. The forearm, however, would not be affected.

E) CORRECT:

Cutaneous anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis, which is most commonly transmitted via contact with infected animals or infected animal products (e.g., wool, hide, meat). The lesions in cutaneous anthrax typically begin as papules that expand and become painless eschars surrounded by extensive edema. Lymphadenopathy is also common. The disease can be accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and headache and rarely progresses to bacteremia or death.

F) INCORRECT:

Primary syphilis can present with a chancre, usually in the genital region. A chancre develops from a painless papule, which goes on to become an ulcer with a raised and indurated margin. However, a necrotic eschar would not be seen and the distribution of this patient's lesions (on the left arm) is not consistent with syphilis.
Image Description:

Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

G) INCORRECT:

A spider bite by the brown recluse spider (which releases a necrotic toxin) can cause a painless papule that progresses to a necrotic black eschar, similar to the lesion seen in this patient. Systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise are sometimes also seen. However, brown recluse spider bites typically become extremely painful within a few hours, and multiple lesions would be unusual.
questions.hint: The picture shows a black eschar characteristic of cutaneous anthrax.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of dyspnea, chest pain, and hemoptysis that were preceded by 4 days of myalgia and a low-grade fever. He is currently visiting the United States as a tourist from Turkey, where he works at a factory that processes sheep wool and hide. An x-ray of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. A sputum culture grows gram-positive rods in gray colonies that have irregular margins with wavy projections on microscopy. Which of the following virulence factors of the causal organism increased its survival in host tissue?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Unlike other bacterial capsules that usually consist of polysaccharides, poly-D-glutamate capsules are formed uniquely by B. anthracis. The glutamate capsule effectively prevents phagocytosis within the host. In addition, B. anthracis produces anthrax toxin, which is formed by three individual components (anthrax protective antigen, edema toxin, and lethal factor) that impair physiological functions in host cells and induce necrosis.

Gastrointestinal anthrax and inhalational anthrax have a particularly poor prognosis, even with antibiotic treatment.
Image Description:

The gram-positive (dark purple) bacteria Bacilli anthracis often form long chains. Each chain link is a single bacterium.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxin B is an exotoxin produced by C. difficile, which causes colonic inflammation and diarrhea, not dyspnea, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Furthermore, while C. difficile is also a gram-positive rod, it does not form “medusa head” colonies.

C) INCORRECT:

Protein A is a virulence factor produced by S. aureus that binds the Fc region of IgG, thereby inhibiting complement system activation and phagocytosis. S. aureus can cause pneumonia. However, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus, unlike the gram-positive rod seen in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is an enzyme secreted by S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria spp. to neutralize secretory immunoglobulin A. Both S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae can cause pneumonia, and pneumococcal pneumonia can cause hemoptysis (rust-colored sputum), which this patient has. However, S. pneumoniae is a gram-positive diplococcus and H. influenzae is a pleomorphic gram-negative bacterium. In addition, neither S. pneumoniae nor H. influenzae cause widening of the mediastinum or formation of “medusa head” colonies. Neisseria spp. are gram-negative diplococci that are not commonly associated with pulmonary disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Sulfatides are a virulence factor of M. tuberculosis. They inhibit phagolysosome fusion in macrophages. Pulmonary infections of M. tuberculosis can manifest with similar symptoms to those seen in this patient but typically follows a much less acute course and would not result in widening of the mediastinum. In addition, while M. tuberculosis is also a gram-positive rod, it usually cultivated for several weeks on special media (e.g., Löwenstein-Jensen medium) and does not form “medusa head” colonies.

F) INCORRECT:

Polysaccharide covers are layers of viscous material making up most bacterial capsules, which protect pathogens from phagocytosis and allow adherence within the host body. However, the capsule of B. anthracis does not consist of a polysaccharide cover.
questions.hint: Acute onset of dyspnea, chest pain, hemoptysis, and widened mediastinum on chest x-ray (due to hemorrhagic mediastinitis) in an individual that handles animal wool and hide is highly suggestive of inhalational anthrax (woolsorter's disease). This condition is caused by inhaling spores formed by Bacillus anthracis, a gram-positive rod that forms irregularly round colonies with wavy projections, referred to as “medusa head” colonies.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a painless lesion on the arm that first appeared 5 days after she visited a petting zoo. The lesion began as a small papule and then became a blister that has since ulcerated. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F). Examination shows a black eschar with edematous borders on the left upper arm. There is axillary lymphadenopathy. The virulence factor responsible for the edema seen in this patient has a mechanism of action similar to which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is an important virulence factor for pathogens that typically infect mucosa-lined structures such as the urogenital and respiratory tracts (e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and Neisseria). It does not play a role in the pathogenesis of cutaneous anthrax.

B) CORRECT:

Edema factor (EF) produced by B. anthracis performs the same function as adenylate cyclase. After undergoing endocytosis, the EF causes a pathological increase in cAMP, which in turn drastically increases water influx into cells. This results in cellular lysis.
Image Description:

Forearm

An ulcer-like lesion with central, black necrosis and sporadic vesicles towards the left margin of the lesion can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Catalase is produced by several species, including Nocardia, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococci. The enzyme degrades hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to water and oxygen, thereby preventing hydrogen peroxide from being used as a substrate for myeloperoxidase and the subsequent production of toxic reactive oxygen species. Although B. anthracis does produce catalase, it is not thought to play a meaningful role in the pathogenesis of cutaneous anthrax.

D) INCORRECT:

Guanylate cyclase is pathologically activated by heat-stable toxin from enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). The typical presentation would be profuse, watery diarrhea after distant travel (“traveler's diarrhea”).

E) INCORRECT:

Lecithinase is the alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens. It acts as a phospholipase and severely damages cellular membranes, resulting in necrotizing fasciitis and other rapidly progressive skin and soft tissue infections. The clinical status of affected individuals deteriorates over a matter of hours, and the affected limb will often show bullae, violaceous discoloration, and extraordinary tenderness accompanied by fever, hypotension, and tachycardia (septic shock). A black eschar would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

SNARE protein function is interrupted by toxins released from Clostridium species, specifically C. tetani and C. botulinum. C. tetani produces the toxin tetanospasmin, which clinically produces spastic paralysis (as seen in tetanus). C. botulinum produces botulinum toxin, which leads to a characteristic flaccid paralysis (as seen in botulism).

G) INCORRECT:

Urease is implicated in the development of struvite stones and peptic ulcers caused by H. pylori. It is not produced by B. anthracis and does not contribute to the pathogenesis of cutaneous anthrax.
questions.hint: This woman has cutaneous anthrax, which typically manifests after a 5–7 day incubation period as a small papule that rapidly progresses to a painless, black eschar with extensive surrounding edema and regional lymphadenopathy. The edema is caused by edema factor produced by Bacillus anthracis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man, who is an infantry soldier, comes to the office because of a 4-day history of fever, headache, myalgias, and a lesion on his face. He first noticed a blister on his right cheek, which gradually progressed into a dark sore. He denies recent insect bites, rodent exposure, or animal bites or scratches, but he scratched his face on the ground during a combat exercise. One week ago, he returned from a 1-year deployment in Afghanistan. The patient's medical history is unremarkable. He appears ill and fatigued. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Physical examination shows a 2-cm painless cutaneous ulcer over the right cheek that is surrounded by an edematous halo; the center of the lesion is necrotic. He has multiple abrasions on his face and elbows. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulceroglandular tularemia typically manifests with fever, skin ulcer, and regional lymphadenopathy, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, individuals with ulceroglandular tularemia usually report recent insect bites (particularly ticks), which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous nocardiosis manifests with nodules that ulcerate and can be accompanied by regional lymphadenopathy, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, the skin lesions in cutaneous nocardiosis are usually painful and this condition is most commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., due to HIV infection, organ transplant, glucocorticoid therapy, diabetes mellitus).

C) CORRECT:

Cutaneous anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis, which is transmitted via contact with infected animals or their products (e.g., wool, hide, meat). It can also be found in soil exposed to infected animal products. This patient was likely exposed when he scratched his face following contact with contaminated soil, providing an entry point for the bacterium or its spores. B. anthracis is endemic in agricultural regions around the world, including central and southwest Asia. The incubation period is typically 5–7 days, after which individuals usually develop a painless, pruritic lesion that ulcerates and becomes a necrotic, black eschar. Local/regional lymphadenopathy, as seen here, is also common. In addition, some patients with cutaneous anthrax develop systemic symptoms, including fever, headache, and myalgias.

In patients with cutaneous anthrax without systemic symptoms, oral monotherapy with a fluoroquinolone (e.g., ciprofloxacin) or doxycycline is usually sufficient; the presence of systemic symptoms, as seen here, warrants intravenous antibiotic therapy with a fluoroquinolone plus linezolid or clindamycin, and antitoxin therapy (e.g., with raxibacumab or anthrax immunoglobulin).
Image Description:

Forearm

An ulcer-like lesion with central, black necrosis and sporadic vesicles towards the left margin of the lesion can be seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis most commonly manifests with painless pustules or ulcers, similar to this patient's lesion. However, patients with sporotrichosis typically develop multiple nodular lesions along lymphatic vessels in the proximity of the primary lesion, forming nodular lymphangitis, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous leishmaniasis manifests with a solitary red skin lesion with central ulceration and regional lymphadenopathy. However, systemic symptoms (e.g., myalgia, fever, headache) are usually not observed in cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Image Description:

A well-demarcated, open, ulcerated wound with overlying purulent exudate is visible on the lateral aspect of the right ankle.

This is the characteristic appearance of cutaneous leishmaniasis.
questions.hint: A painless, necrotic eschar is a characteristic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of several painless, pruritic lesions on his left forearm that he first noticed 4 days ago. The lesions began as pink marks, progressed to blisters, and then ulcerated. He also reports a headache for the past week. His temperature is 38.1°C. A photograph of one of the lesions is provided. There is pronounced edema of the surrounding skin and painless swelling of the left axillary lymph nodes. Which one of the following is the strongest risk factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Swimming in pools is a risk factor for Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis (hot tub folliculitis). It typically develops within 48 hours after exposure to the pathogen in pools or tubs and presents with tender and pruritic papules, pustules, or nodules. Most patients can have associated malaise and low-grade fever. However, an isolated necrotic eschar would not be seen.

B) CORRECT:

Cutaneous anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis, which is most commonly transmitted via contact with infected animals or infected animal products (e.g., wool, hide, meat). The lesions in cutaneous anthrax typically begin as papules that expand and become painless eschars surrounded by extensive edema. Lymphadenopathy is also common. The disease can be accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and headache and rarely progresses to bacteremia or death.

Key learning point: Handling wool or other animal products is the strongest risk factor for cutaneous anthrax, which presents as painless eschars with surrounding edema and possible systemic symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Cat scratch disease, caused by Bartonella henselae transmitted from cat scratches or bites, causes lesions that begin as a single papule or pustule. However, the hallmark sign of the disease is the development of tender regional lymphadenopathy. A necrotic eschar would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is associated with several cutaneous infections, including necrobiosis lipoidica and acanthosis nigricans. In uncontrolled diabetics, necrotic eschars may form in conjunction with mucormycosis, usually seen in the facial region. The forearm, however, would not be affected.

E) INCORRECT:

A spider bite by the brown recluse spider (which releases a necrotic toxin) can cause a painless papule that progresses to a necrotic black eschar, similar to the lesion seen in this patient. Systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise are sometimes also seen. However, brown recluse spider bites typically become extremely painful within a few hours, and multiple lesions would be unusual.
questions.hint: The picture shows a black eschar characteristic of cutaneous anthrax.
